xxl.core.cursors.filters

Class Filter<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.SecureDecoratorCursor<E>
      • xxl.core.cursors.filters.Filter<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    RegionQuery, Sampler, Selection, SpatialJoin

    public class Filter<E>
extends SecureDecoratorCursor<E>
    A filter is a decorator-cursor that selects the iteration's elements with the help of a user defined predicate (or boolean function for backward compatibility). Only those elements, for which the specified unary function applied on that element returns Boolean.TRUE, are returned by next or peek. If a predicate is used instead, the elements of the decorated input cursor are selected by evaluating this predicate for each element. So only the elements are returned, where the predicate's evaluation result is true.

    The implementation of the next method is as follows: 

         if (computedHasNext)
         return hasNext;
     for (; super.hasNext(); super.next())
         if (predicate.invoke(super.peek()))
             return true;
     return false;

    Note: If the input iteration is given by an object of the class Iterator, i.e., it does not support the peek operation, it is internally wrapped to a cursor.

    Example usage : 

         Filter<Integer> filter = new Filter<Integer>(
         new Enumerator(11),
         new Function<Integer, Boolean>() {
             public Boolean invoke(Integer next) {
                 return next % 2 == 0;
             }
         }
     );
 
     filter.open();
 
     while(filter.hasNext())
         System.out.println(filter.next());
 
     filter.close();
    This example demonstrates the filter functionality. This filter returns only the even elements of the input enumerator, because the defined unary function only returns Boolean.TRUE, if the integer value of the object modulo 2 is equal to 0.

    Example usage when defining a predicate instead: 

         Filter<Integer> filter = new Filter<Integer>(
         new Enumerator(11),
         new Predicate<Integer>() {
             public boolean invoke(Integer next) {
                 return next % 2 == 0;
             }
         }
     );
 
     filter.open();
 
     while(filter.hasNext())
         System.out.println(filter.next());
 
     filter.close();
    This example demonstrates the filter functionality implemented by using an unary predicate. The result is exactly the same as in the first example!

    See Also:
    Iterator, Cursor, SecureDecoratorCursor, Function, Predicate

    • Constructor Detail

      • Filter

        public Filter(Iterator<E> iterator,
              Predicate<? super E> predicate)
        Creates a new filter by decorating the input iterator. The input iterator is wrapped to a cursor, if the peek functionality is not supported.
        Parameters:
        iterator - the input iterator containing the elements to be filtered.
        predicate - the unary predicate used to select the elements.

      • Filter

        public Filter(Iterator<E> iterator,
              Function<? super E,Boolean> function)
        Creates a new filter by decorating the input iterator. The input iterator is wrapped to a cursor, if the peek functionality is not supported. The boolean function is internally wrapped to a predicate.
        Parameters:
        iterator - the input iterator containing the elements to be filtered.
        function - the boolean, unary function used to select the elements.

    • Method Detail

      • hasNext

        public boolean hasNext()
                throws IllegalStateException
        Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

        The implementation is as follows: 

             if (computedHasNext)
         return hasNext;
     for (; super.hasNext(); super.next())
         if (predicate.invoke(super.peek()))
             return true;
     return false;
        Only those elements for which the specified predicate returns true are returned by next or peek.
        Specified by:
        hasNext in interface Iterator<E>
        Specified by:
        hasNext in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        hasNext in class SecureDecoratorCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the filter has more elements.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.
